DataElement.preferredName: Superior Mesenteric Artery Surgical Margin Resection Status
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Information about the status of the superior mesenteric artery margin of surgical resection.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Superior Mesenteric Artery Surgical Margin Resection
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: An artery arising from the abdominal aorta with numerous branches that supply the intestines from the duodenum to the transverse colon and the pancreas._One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical._The act of cutting out; the surgical removal of part or all of a structure or organ.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: An artery arising from the abdominal aorta with numerous branches that supply the intestines from the duodenum to the transverse colon and the pancreas.:One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.

Concepts.definition: An artery arising from the abdominal aorta with numerous branches that supply the intestines from the duodenum to the transverse colon and the pancreas.

One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.

Property.preferredDefinition: (ree-SEK-shun) Removal of tissue or part or all of an organ by surgery.

Concepts.definition: The surgical removal of a lesion, often as part of a biopsy and with healthy margins.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: any measurements of a patient's surgical margins.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: a state indicating presence or absence of malignant cells at the surgical border where tumor tissue was removed from a patient.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A finding of normality following an examination or investigation looking for the presence of a microorganism, disease, or condition.

Concepts.definition: A finding of normality following an examination or investigation looking for the presence of a microorganism, disease, or condition.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An operation in which a term denies or inverts the meaning of another term or construction.: Having been subjected to inspection or evaluation.

Concepts.definition: An operation in which a term denies or inverts the meaning of another term or construction.
Having been subjected to inspection or evaluation.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: attributes of a patient's laboratory sample, including the source, condition, and fixative.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Status; a condition or state at a particular time.

Concepts.definition: A condition or state at a particular time.
